<@U0A6V6PHS>: I have been following this with some interest.  What are your thoughts as a math department insider? Yeah, so without going into too much excruciating detail, the whole thing is a _little_ controversial, but it's being blown way out of proportion as is wont to happen.
The math department did _not_ fire the man because he was too good at teaching, full stop.
Simply not what happened.

What did happen is that Alexander was very forceful about his fairly unorthodox views on teaching a course like calculus, to the point where he explicitly refused to follow recommendations from the department chair.
(e.g. Please at least assign some homework problems from the textbook, even if you don't grade it.)
This was during his first semester of teaching at Berkeley, which was also the first semester the department was trying out hiring "lecturers" to handle teaching a few of the larger classes.
So in general it would have been accurate to describe his interactions in the department as "uncooperative".

His other main failing was probably in course administration - I was a GSI for him in his first semester, and in general things were rather disorderly.  He didn't communicate what was happening in the course to the GSIs, and many of his students were unclear about what was expected of them.
So I would say that these are the main actual reasons the department decided not to renew his contract.

sorry, I didn't mean to ignite the anti-Matlab crusade
but just to weigh in on a couple of things:

1) Matlab and other closed-source tools are used by more than just "pockets of clueless engineers" who are "churning huge volumes of useless shit."  I agree that reproducibility is important, and that there is a nontrivial amount of useless junk and/or outright fraud.  However, that kind of unilateral claim is nonproductive (and frankly pretty offensive).

2) <@U0C0XE7CZ> is right in that a huge chunk of science is not actually dependent on proprietary algorithms, even if it's analyzed with a closed-source software.  I work with a ton of biologists who do biomechanics of locomotion.  The meat of their data is the outputs of the various bits of hardware that they use.  If and when they use Matlab, it's to do statistical analysis on those data (which is why SO MANY of them still use Excel argh).  So in fact, the raw data does not and never will be produced or altered by software (unless you count the drivers of your force sensor or whatever).  It would be reproducible with an open-source platform in that case (which is to say, most organismal biology).

3) "get the thing to do the thing you want" is not a general skillset.  I think everyone who's ever gotten a PhD has gotten some FLAVOR of this skillset; for me, it was mostly "drink beers with the right people at the right conferences, and then they will show you their labs and cool techniques that you can adapt for your own use."  So I'm skilled at manipulating human resources, and I'm decently skilled at hacking together hardware and/or experimental setups in a machine shop or wherever, but I have never gotten the knack of delving into open-source land.

(that's not an excuse-- I'd love to pick up more programming skills and move away from proprietary software.  I'm just pointing out that "getting what you need" is a really diverse skillset, and having one flavor of this skill doesn't imply that you will be able to pick up others easily.)

I think <@U0A6T0LNT> is right in that what we need is a revolution from the lowest levels: teach a required course in K-12 to start students off in thinking algorithmically and give them a broad base for learning many different software tools.  All the programming classes I've ever had were based entirely within one language /framework (Java, Matlab, etc), which isn't helpful for building broad-based thinking of the type we're discussing.

But until then, how do we lower the barrier to entry for open source technology?  <@U0C0XE7CZ> has a real point in that often, the technology is unrelated to the actual analysis, so there's not a lot of incentive to adopt a technology solution that is more complex than the out-of-the-box software.

Maybe a good place to start would be to ask people why they don't use open source platforms.  For me, I know that a huge barrier is the number of choices you have to make up-front (what compiler? what environment? what interface?).  If you aren't familiar with the terminology, it can be very daunting to be asked to make so many choices for something about which you know almost nothing.

file.preview:
In addition to importing (or exporting) works information, in some cases the tools also will capture your ORCID iD and insert it into the external data record in the database you are accessing. This is how your iD is added to your existing works, and is the basis for how Scopus, Web of Science, and EuropePMC offer functionality to search their databases by ORCID iD. Many researchers report that they also identify works for which that they didn’t realize they had been listed as a co-author. 

Most of you are familiar with Scopus and Researcher ID. CrossRef is a database of all journal articles that have a DOI. DataCite is a database of all datasets that have been issued a DOI.  If you have published a paper or dataset in the last 10 years, you likely will find it using these Wizards.

text: academics have the power to change how their sector operates... if they want to
I think this is true but at our level, you definitely get into the dichotomy between "abandon the sinking ship" vs. "play the game until you have enough power to make real change"

There are a ton of issues with the academy, and a lot of external pressures on the way it operates (unsustainably rising tuition costs, the rise of online education, for-profit colleges, the budding reformation of scientific publishing, etc)-- I think we are about to see a paradigm shift that will determine whether the university continues to be a driving force of innovation, or fades into irrelevance.  The question is whether you want to get the hell away from the tower of cards before it collapses, or stick around so that you can snag a key role in the rebuilding process.
devil's advocate: how many people go into politics/government/business/finance/law/X to "play the game until they had enough power to make real change"?
I can imagine a system tuned to do very well by feeding off of those dynamics
a system that takes your best years and intentions, bends the less-idealistic, more-ambitious personalities to fit the mold, and pariahs the few radicals who don't drop out or fall in line
a system that fills its upper ranks with the most ambitious with the fewest qualms—the winners of the race-to-the-bottom—and that is _very_ robust to change
I think most of the enduring edifices in modern society have most of these qualities, by necessity
Well, the systems that still exist in the world tend to be very robust against agitators.
Exactly.
Otherwise, they wouldn't be enduring.
and I think that academia is an extreme example of where that can take you
(to a place that makes absolutely no sense)
a system that has evolved so that if you are subject to that system's constraints, then your range of action is constrained to align with the system's interests
e.g. teaching at universities needs a major overhaul
I care a lot about teaching
in a sane world, I would assume a role that takes my interest and skills and work in that area as an input and provides money, professional standing, and administrative power as an output
but this is academia, so "I cannot let you do that, Star Fox"
you can match the inputs, and take the role of instructor
for little pay and no power or respect
(good luck being invited to departmental meetings, and if you are you're 'just a lecturer')
or you can try to match the outputs, and take the role of faculty member
where everything related to teaching will be <10% of your time

but they'll actually pay you and your coworkers will respect your 'professional opinion', and in ten years, you might be a junior member in the administrative orgs that make decisions about what is taught, how it's taught, and who teaches it
(though, your 'preoccupation with education' will be a handicap while climbing that ladder)
it wouldn't be hard to come up with another example, for someone who wants to develop a solution to one of humanity's Grand Challenges
the inefficiency of all of the overhead and bureaucracy and the bizarre top-down funding models are innovation-crushing
a few places like MIT have created a culture and an infrastructure that gets around those problems

the vast majority of places are more like Berkeley, and they're playing catchup and trying to figure out how to 'encourage innovation' for entirely economic reasons (and totally misunderstanding the cultural component)
if you're someone interested in creating and working on valuable new intellectual property, you can embrace the academic bureaucracy and sign away a huge amount of control over your own ideas
...in exchange for the institution's name and a steady paycheck...?
or you can _not_ do that
the cost and risk of 'playing the game until you can rewrite the rules' in either of those contexts is immense

I mean, it's pretty cynical to suggest that change is impossible.  You mentioned teaching.  I know a good handful of faculty members who DO care about teaching-- they care about it a lot.  And they're not just lecturers, or faculty at teaching colleges (though some are).  But they're not treated with professional disdain-- they're some of the most respected people in their fields.  And these types of people are becoming more and more common. True, right now they're a small minority.  But twenty years ago, they were a SUPER TINY minority.  There are whole journals and conferences-- active ones!-- dedicated to pedagogy research that didn't exist even ten years ago.  I can even see the difference over my five years in grad school: going to the same conference for four years in a row, the number of sessions and panels that are specifically focused on engineering education have more than doubled.

So it's not really fair to equate "caring about teaching" with "not respected."  Focusing on research to the detriment of teaching is obviously still widespread and a problem, but to say we're not making progress is absurd.
I have noticed that biologists tend to care a lot more about teaching than engineers, so maybe my perspective is different because I rarely work with people who are "pure" engineers.
and you mentioned politics-- this week there was a great example of "make-it-to-the-top-and-then-effect-change" with Trudeau's cabinet appointments in Canada
pretty dramatic

Norway did a similar thing in the 80s-- their first female prime minister had a cabinet that was 40% female (big shift at the time), and gender parity was way better off in their government even after she left
